intro: Polypogon higegaweri f. muticus, commonly known as the silent higegaweri grass, is a rare and lesser-known grass species belonging to the Poaceae family. It is characterized by its slender, tufted growth habit and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as sandy soils or rocky areas, preferring full sun exposure. Its inflorescence consists of a dense spikelet cluster, which is often reduced in size compared to other members of the genus. Due to its limited distribution and unique morphology, it is of interest to botanists studying plant adaptation and genetic diversity.
